Saying a star 'dies' or goes through 2 death cycles is anthropomorphizing it a bit much, don't you think? It's a pretty standard process for gravity wells that gain this size. Nothing has 'died'

a Gravity well is a 3-dimensional hole in space time that matter falls into. We have different names for the same phenomenon, usually based on size and what we see it doing from the outside. Whether your size-based naming scheme calls it a moon or a black hole, they are the same phenomenon and the only thing separating them is mass, spin and composition.

you covered pretty well that the accelerative force of gravity and the mega explosions caused when gravity forces a collapse and subsequent supernovae explosion, fuse lighter elements into denser elements.

This is the purpose of gravity. It collects the hydrogen, helium and trace amounts of lithium that were made in the big bang and it transforms them through intense heat and pressure in ever larger gravity wells and gravitational collapse/explosions all the way through the periodic table from least dense to most.

Gravity, the weakest of the 4 fundamental forces is precisely the accelerative force that overcomes the other forces and creates the variation in the density of matter that we see on the periodic table.

Of course, by the time you get to a neutron star, the only thing holding that degenerate matter together is GRAVITY. The acceleration at the surface of a neutron star is too great for it to decompress a little or express its mass over a larger area (becoming less dense). The gravitational acceleration is so intense that it holds the neutron star in a very tight circle in spite of a very rapid rotation that in smaller bodies would result in some level of oblateness.

the difference between a black hole and a neutron star is Mass density. Two colliding neutron stars are a good example of two deep gravitational wells coming together to create one gravity well that is deep enough that the surface acceleration of the degenerate neutron matter is exceeding the speed of light. The point in the gravity well where that acceleration speed limit is breached is called the event horizon or the Schwarzschild radius.

Now you have a very small black hole, they get truly massive before they get to the point where they again collapse in on themselves, this time into a singularity followed by a massive explosion creating Hydrogen, helium and trace amounts of lithium from all that degenerate matter that was held together inside.

If that sounds familiar, it should. Gravity is the recycler of matter from its humble origin all the way through the periodic table and back into pure potential and another big bang

SPIN, CORE DYNAMICS AND MAGNETISM:
For a gravity well in rotation, (like the earth or a neutron star) If you take 3 identical clocks, one in unaccelerated space, one on the surface and one at the core. You'll note through general relativity that the clock in deep space runs faster than the clock on the surface, and that surface clock is running faster than the clock at the core.

this means that as the surface rotates around, the core will super rotate ahead of the crust. this is gravitational acceleration in the spin direction. time is slower at the core than at the surface. So, in spite of immense friction and in the vacuum of space, we have a core that spins faster that the subsequent layers of strata.

It's this GR phenomenon that creates the intense magnetic field on neutron stars and also our own magnetic field here on earth.

It seems like neutron stars could help in answering the Fermi Paradox. It would take a few generations of star-formation to lead to the collisions of neutron stars that end up producing many of the heavy/trace elements that are necessary for the metabolic pathways of complex life. But there also will be a period in the early universe (which may be ending around now) where neutron star collisions (and the gamma-ray bursts they occasion) are too frequent for the galaxies in which they occur to be hospitable for the rise of life (or, some complex life may emerge, even intelligent life, but it would be doomed to be wiped out by the next gamma-ray burst). In this way, we can see that neutron star collisions would be both necessary for life (especially complex life), but at the same time would be lethal to life, for a certain period of time. It may be, that it is only after a few generations of star-formation into the universe, that life like ours has a real prospect of emerging & surviving, long-term. The reason why there's no one out there, is because we are one of the very first ones, out there...

Pulsars are rotating neutron stars. Most neutron stars discovered today are in the form of radio pulsars. They are called radio pulsars because they emit radio waves. We can simply connect a radio telescope to a loud speaker and hear a pulsar. Pulsars sound like someone persistently knocking. So in short, we can hear a pulsar knock.

Quran, Chapter no. 86 (Surah At-Taariq : Chapter of Pulsar), Verse no. 1-3:
By the sky and the night knocker.
وَٱلسَّمَآءِ وَٱلطَّارِقِ (1)
And what can make you know what is the night knocker?
(2)وَمَآ أَدْرَىٰكَ مَا ٱلطَّارِقُ
˹It is˺ the star of piercing brightness.
(3)ٱلنَّجْمُ ٱلثَّاقِبُ

"Taariq الطَّارِقُ" means the one who knocks. The Arabic word "Thuqb ثقب" means a hole; "Thaaqib ثَّاقِبُ" means the one who makes a hole. The Quran is describing a knocking star that makes a hole (Distorted Spacetime).

Pulsars are rotating neutron stars. As more matter falls into a neutron star its mass increases, and as its mass increases its gravity increases. But gravity is curvature of spacetime. A neutron star distorts spacetime. The more matter falls into a neutron star the more distortion it makes. A point will be reached where distortion would have grown so much that it makes a hole in spacetime.

One of the most fascinating sci-fi books I ever read, Dragon's Egg by Robert Forward, posited a way that sentient life could evolve on a neutron star! While we pass electrons in our chemistry, the "cheela," which look like tiny slugs with multiple eyestalks, pass neutrons. The elctromagnetic force is what largely holds us together; the strong nuclear force is what holds the cheela together. The home star even has starquakes (usually when a mountain collapses) and weather, which influences their society just as it does ours.

We arrive, by sheer accident, when the cheela are in a barbaric phase, and the lights of our monopole countergravity bodies bootstrap them into astronomy and ultimately, civilization. All in a single night - the cheela live thousands of times faster than we do, since nuclear chemistry takes place at MUCH higher energies than our water-based chemistry.

Just the sheer insanity of the premise - the birth of a civilization on a neutron star is so far fetched that only a master astrophysicist could pull it off, and he does. Dragon's Egg and its sequel "Starquake* can be hard to find but are well worth reading.

Step 1: Wait until it runs out of fuel.
Step 2: If it becomes a neutron star, then collide it with another neutron star.

Step 5: If it is now a black dwarf, wait till the end of the universe for it to be destroyed by quantum tunneling.

I'd like to make a very hasty correction for this video.
Nuclear Fusion merges two atoms to form a heavier one (Mass number) And releasing enormous energy to fight back the gravitational pull of a star

Kurzgesagt stated that Hydrogen > Helium > Carbon > Neon > Oxygen > Silicon > Fe (Nuclear ash)

Neon is actually heavier than Oxygen in terms of the Mass number. So the correct order should be :-
Hydrogen > Helium > Carbon > Oxygen > Neon > Silicon > Fe

I hope this solves some confusion or misunderstandings. Big up Kurz!

THE MOST DEADLY AND DANGEROUS OBSERVABLE THING IN THE UNIVERSE
• Gravitation
Neutron stars are city-size stellar objects with a mass about 1.4 times that of the sun and 10 km in diameter. Gravity presses the material in on itself so tightly that protons and electrons combine to make neutrons, yielding the name "neutron star". They are so dense that a sugar cube sized lump of material from a neutron star would have a weight of approximately 1 billion metric tons (equivalent to the weight of Everest mountain). If a sugar cubed sized matter could be scooped out from a neutron star, it would explode immediately due to the lack of gravitaion. Because the only thing which can hold the nuclei of atoms so close together is the gravitaional force of a neutron star. So neutron star matter wouldn't be able survive out of a neutron star. Inside a neutron star, there's a delicate balance between the tremendous gravity of the star, and the degeneracy pressure of the neutrons. The neutron star's density also gives it very high surface gravity, more than 200 billion times that of Earth. Neutron stars have an escape velocity of 150,000 km/s which is half the speed of light. The neutron star's gravity accelerates infalling matter to tremendous speed. The force of the impact would destroy the object's atoms, rendering all the matter identical, to the rest of the neutron star. If an object were to fall from a height of one meter on a neutron star, it would reach the ground at  7.200.000 kilometers per hour.
• Starquake and Gama Rays Burst
The crust is composed of broken-up atoms of iron with a sea of electrons flowing through the gaps between them. This crust is extremely hard and very smooth (with maximum surface irregularities of ~5 mm), due to the extreme gravitational field. About a kilometer below the surface, neutrons and any surviving protons are squeezed together so close that they organize themselves into some really odd structures such as sheets, cylinders and others. This inner crust of neutron star, which was called nuclear pasta because of the resemblance to spaghetti and lasagna, could be 10 billion times stronger than steel and possibly the strongest material in the universe. Due to either its ultra-strong interior magnetic fields or spindown, an unimaginably massive quake occurs by ripping the immensely strong crust only one centimeter in lenght in a tenth of a second. It realeses much more energy in a form of gama rays into the space through that one centimeter crack than the Sun emits in 150,000 years. But the inconceivably powerful gravitaional field of a neutron star reconstructs its surface and covers the crack in a blink of an eye. The largest recorded quake was equivalent to a magnitude 23. Had it occurred within a distance of 10 light years from Earth, the quake could have triggered a mass extinction on Earth.
• Surface Heat
Neutron stars are extremely hot and have  surface temperature varying from 10.000.000 to 500.000 C degrees. Anything approaching a neutron star too close immidiately evaporates.
• Electromagnetic Field
Neutron stars are characterized by their extremely powerful magnetic fields. These magnetic fields are from hundred millions to quadrillions (magnetar) of times more powerful than the field surrounding Earth. The magnetic field of a magnetar would be lethal even at a distance of 1000 km. The strong magnetic forces would start to squeeze the electron orbits in all the atoms in your body. The molecules that make up your body are only able to hold together when they are made from normal shaped atoms. So once the atomic orbitals got sufficiently distorted, their chemistry would change dramatically and these molecules would start to fall apart. And your body would be instantly reduced to a dusty, incoherent mess.
• Electromagnetic radiation
Most of the light generated by a neutron star is in the form of gama and X rays due to its extreme surface heat, high electromagnetic field and matter acceretion from a near companion. The strong magnetic fields combined with rapid rotation create an awesome generator that can produce electric potential differences of quadrillions of volts. Such voltages, which are 30 million times greater than those of lightning bolts, create deadly blizzards of high energy particles. These high-energy particles (protons and electrons) produce beams of radiation from radio through gamma-ray energies emanating from the poles of the magnetic field. Like a rotating lighthouse beam, the radiation can be observed as a pulsing source of radiation. The pulsar in the Crab Nebula has been observed to pulse in almost every wavelength—radio, optical, X-ray, and gamma-ray.
• Rotation
Neutron stars are the fastest rotating objects in the universe. The fastest-spinning neutron star known, which is 15 kilometres in diameter, is rotating at a rate of 716 times a second or 43,000 revolutions per minute, giving nearly a quarter the speed of light (75.000 km/s) on the surface of equator.
Even a neutron star wouldn't be able to hold itself together at such a high speed rotation if it weren't for its tremendous gravitational force.

Actually, the supernova is not the rebounding of the outer parts of the star on the iron core, models show that the shockwave of the rebound stalls very quickly in the extremely dense material close to the core. Astrophysicists now theorize  that the supernova is actually powered by an intense burst of neutrinos produced in the creation of neutrons from the fusion of electrons and protons....This is amazing because neutrinos do not interact with matter hardly at all. It has been said that a neutrino could pass through several lightyears thickness of lead without interacting. A little insight into the nature of the matter close to the iron core of a pre-supernova. We can barely comprehend what this matter must be like, in the instant before the supernova explosion.

An interesting related topic is: primordial black holes

These are theorized stellar sized black holes which could only have formed in the earliest moment of the universe.
Essentially, the very early moments of the universe is theorized to have been a quark-gluon plasma and very minute differences in density would have caused the formation of stellar sized black holes. These have not yet been observed.

The cores of neutron stars are also theorized to be quark-gluon plasma. Which is interesting if you consider that you would expect to see evidence of neutron stars randomly collapsing into a black hole due to the same principle of minute density variations.


I wonder which will be proven out? Primordial black holes existing or nailing down the physical existence of quark-gluon plasma in the core of neutron stars?

The theories at least, seem mutually exclusive...

One of the phrases I hate most is "most extreme."  Extreme is extreme. It's an absolute. You can't have something more extreme that that which is already extreme. People ought to say and write "most nearly extreme,"  as in 99.999...% as compared to 100%.  It's like saying "more complete," or "more perfect"  (as in the book A More Perfect Union). How can something be more perfect than perfect? It's already perfect, an ultimate quality; therefore cannot be more perfect. Should we also try "more infinite?"  What can be more infinite than infinite?

But then an avatar of Helium comes along, all buff and strong, all fresh and full of energy. The repulsion mentioned at 2:05 is because an atom is quantum mechanical. Think of it like a theater, with the electrons only being in the same seat, or energy level, if they have different spins, because they're fermions with spin 0.5 or -0.5, so identical electrons can't be in the same seat. That keeps them from crashing into the screen (okay, it's actually the nucleus), so they need a huge amount of pressure to do that, like the pressure in neutron stars, for example.

Thanks Neutron Stars.

In a kilonova, the heavy nuclei fall apart and some of the neutrons decay into protons. But the atomic nuclei are pulled in by the black hole's gravity. But how do the nuclei escape from the black hole? Well, when the neutrons decayed, they used beta decay. In beta decay, the neutrons have to emit W- bosons to turn into protons. You're saying, "But how can W bosons play a part in this?" Well, they can't, but they decay into electrons and electron antineutrinos. The electrons can't help, but surprisingly, the neutrinos can! We usually think they don't interact much, but the momentum gives the nuclei a boost. In fact, it's enough to push the nuclei out of the black hole's reach. Remember, the black hole's gravity gets weaker the further something is from it. And that's how the nuclei escape to land here on Earth, bond to each other, and give us a hint on this topic that I just explained. Thanks for reading!

neutron stars start to show many characteristics of black holes, with the almost similar densities and their bending of light around it, etc. is it not then more plausible to uniformly suggest that a black hole is just a more dense neutron star, who’s gravity is so strong, rather than just bend light around it, it now traps it as well. if light no longer reflects off of its surface (elementary: light bouncing off of an object back to its observer is what send the message of what something looks like) it’s effectively rendering it an invisible-ish object in space. this to me seems more logical than a black hole being a worm hole or a rip in the fabric of time. thoughts?

a neutron star rotates at a rate of ~700 rotations per second. think about that. grab a fidget spinner right now and spin that thing as hard as you can. you’ll MAYBE get out about 6000 rotations per minute. that’s about 104 per second. a damn neutron star rotates at ~6.7x the rate of what you’re seeing in your hand, account for its mass and speed and it’s spinning at a 5th of the speed of light. that’s fucking fascinating.

I'm not buying the claim that most of the heavy elements in the universe came from merging neutron stars. Neutron stars merging is a very rare event because neutron stars are rare, and there's WAY too much heavy elements out there to be accounted for by that. We're not just talking about the gold but the lead. Also, you are wrong to claim the inch tall mountains on the surface of neutron stars are many times the mass of the himalayas. They aren't. It's only the material deep inside the neutron star that is actually super dense. The stuff at the surface is just ordinary matter and has ordinary densities, you have to get at least a bit down before there's actually any PRESSURE you see. It isn't the GRAVITY that crushes matter to extreme densities, it's PRESSURE, and the pressure AT the surface is essentially zero, so no, the "mountains" would not be super dense or more massive than the himalayas.

Cool video, but there are some missing points about these magnificent objects. For instance, the magnetic field strength of a typical neuron star (radio pulsar) is around 1e12 G (100.000.000 Tesla). Magnetars are a special type among the neutron stars. Magnetars have magnetic field strengths around 1e13 - 1e15 G (so it is up to 100.000.000.000 Tesla) inferred from the period and period derivative of the neutron stars. Beside that, starting from the conservation of angular momentum, it is possible to conclude that neutron stars have to rotate very fast, and it is measured for many of them. Their rotational periods vary from milliseconds to few seconds. You can compare that period with Sun' s which is 24.5 days (2114208 s) and calculate how fast it has to rotate, if we shrink it to a size of a neutron star. Furthermore, period of neutron stars change very slowly (mostly varies from 1e-12 s/s to 1e-18 s/s).

We don't know everything about the inside of the neutron stars. On the other hand, we know one thing very well. The inside of the neutron stars are super conductors and super fluids, and the neutron stars are rotating which means that they have angular momentum. About the super fluids, their curls are zero, which means that they can not rotate. To sustain the conservation of the angular momentum, in somewhere inside the neutron star, angular momentum should be carried. That part is sustained by the vortex lines inside the super fluids which contains normal matter which can carry the angular momentum and rotate. Beside these, there are magnetic flux tubes which carry the magnetic fields. Vortex tubes and magnetic flux tubes can be pinned and unpinned, and these kind of interactions can explain different behaviors of the neutron stars, and it is beyond the scope for now.

After these extra information, neutron stars are really amazing objects.

Iron nuclei can still be fused by sufficiently massive stars into more massive nuclei though this currently isn't believed to be the primary source of most of the heavier elements. However, fusion of iron nuclei and/or other, more massive, nuclei consumes energy with the consumed energy being converted into mass following following Einstein's mass/energy equivalence (i.e. the net mass ---> energy conversion, which balances the collapsing force of gravity and the explosive force of nuclear energy, eventually becomes a net energy --> mass conversion, which means less and less explosive force while simultaneously ramping up the crushing force of gravity)

We found that particles in the core would be so packed together, that the concept of temperature breaks down.  The Pauli exclusion principle would literally prevent the transfer of thermal energy to or from the material, because all energy states are already occupied.  This means that, if you were somehow able to put your hand on the core material of a neutron star, it would feel as if it were the same temperature as your hand.  It would not melt ice.  It would not cool hot steel.

They're the third most extreme thing. Overdense Neutron Stars (Quark Stars) are more extreme. Now it's pretty obvious that on the way to a black hole they should exist as a neutron's density is in the realm of 10^17 kg/m^3 while a black hole's is 10^19 kg/m^3 and a quark's is 10^18 kg/m^3. While a neutron star has collapsed the atoms, a quark star has collapsed the neucleons. This is hypothetical, but there are a number of neutron stars which are probable candidates. There are additionally strange stars (a type of quark star) and white holes (which are theorized from the same place as black holes, but have no evidence for existence), however neither of these have evidence to support them as do Quark Stars.

OK. Whit dwarfs are around 1.74 sun's in mass. It becomes denser as it gets older. Massive stars such as U.Y scuti will explode into supernova making a white dwarf. Strange matter inside of neutron stars at the core are broken quarks. Kilnova are very dangerous, if you were to stand in a kilnova you would be slowly chewed away a very boring death.
Edit: Neutron stars are a very Compact object in space. They spin every few seconds causing a turbulent magnetic field. Suprisingly due to their high density they are smaller than asteroids.

All great facts, there are some additional facts about neutron stars (and magnetars) that Kurzgesagt didn't mention:
- If you (or anything else) fall into a neutron star, you will be spaghettified and hit the star at a fraction of speed of light, and the ensuring impact will be energetic enough to be detected from afar. Your remains wouldn't be sticking out much either, having been compacted and vaporized and fused into the crust.
- The neutron's star magnetic field is so strong that it can wipe out all the magnetic storage off the earth if it gets too close. The selfsame magnetic field would kill you too, but to be fair, this was demonstrated by one of Kurzgezagt's patron birds.
- Magnetars has a magnetic field so strong that it can even buckle its own crust. Considering how incredible dense the neutron star's crust were, the ensuring starquake is so strong that it rings violently like a bell. Incidentally, these starquakes would cause mass extinctions to any nearby habitable planet, even if they had somehow survived the supernova before that.

As an astronomer, I need to say: awesome video! Neutron stars are amazing objects.

I wanted to add a small detail to the introduction about stars. This is perhaps a little nitpicky, but it's a common misconception, so I'd like to elaborate a bit.
Before nuclear fusion begins and is able to produce the energy to counteract gravity, the star is upheld by the heat of its compressed plasma. This produces enough photon pressure to prevent the star from collapsing before it is able to start fusion. It is however a much smaller reservoir of energy than fusion, so the star will shrink slowly during this time, until it reaches the critical density where hydrogen can start to fuse into helium. In the case that the star is not heavy enough, it will never fuse hydrogen and it is called a brown dwarf.

So while stars are often described as having nuclear fusion as the mechanism to prevent it from collapsing, it is not a necessary ingredient to be called a star. Also neutron stars, as so nicely explained in the video, do not actively fuse elements. Still they are very worthy of the name star! :-)

For anyone wondering at 7:09 , the poster behind the guitarist is an actual album cover for the band Joy Division, "Unknown Pleasures".
The cover is actually the first recording of a Pulsar, discovered by a student in the University of Cambridge in 1967. They had no idea what this signal was back then, and since it came in regular intervals, wild speculation about the possibility of the signal being of Extraterrestrial origins came about. Its name, LGM-1, even grants credence to this, standing for “Little Green Men”.

That leaves an interesting dilemma. If neutron stars tend to provide elements required for advanced technological society, then to find intelligent life in the cosmos, we should probably look towards locations that once had a binary neutron star system nearby. When we look through telescopes, we look at the past, so such systems we see in the sky today, may actually hold intelligent species looking back today. Rather than looking for life in the sky, we should look for death and rebirth.

Some minor remarks:
- Helium/Hydrogen is not exhausted. It is just that more and more heavier elements collect in the core, which can not (jet) be fused.
- Stars are not held up by radiation pressure but by regular thermal pressure (and later degenerate electron pressure)
- During the supernova the outer layers are driven out by intense neutrino(!) radiation. The bounce is generally not enough

Normale Neutronen können nicht so ohne weiteres aus Protonen und Eletronen aufgebaut werden. Aber Hyper-Neutronen können aus Hyper-Protonen und Eletronen aufgebaut werden (ein Nukleon mehr). Sie haben mehr Dichte und sind in normalen Sonnen aufgebaut. Auch Hyper-Hyper-Neutronen sind vorstellbar. Warum sollten Neutronensterne so oft zusammenbrechen, das wäre Unsinn.Schwarze Löcher sind auf diese Weise unmöglich.Sie qären nur als ausgedehnte Positronen-Gaps kosmischen Ausmaßes in einer Elektronenblase denkbar ,einschließlich Neutrinokernen in verschiedenen Blasen beider Elementarteilchen.Auch dann lägen nur gegenläufige Teilchen vor.

The coolest thing about a neutron star is the the process it goes through when adding mass and shrinking, which is not in this video. The neutron star initially collapses until all the neutrons occupy all the space. Particles can’t occupy the same space so the collapse stops. As the star accretes mass the star becomes more massive, but also smaller. How can this happen when the particles are already as close together as they can get? The answer is the uncertainty principle. You can either know where a particle is or where it is going. Neutrons in the star know their location more precisely but their movement is less precisely known and that means the neutrons can press a little closer together, shrinking the star, until eventually black hole is formed.

Can anyone explain why the iron "crust" of neutron stars (Described in the video as a crystal lattice) remains a solid crust rather than liquifying considering the temperature of the star and the fact that they are made of a layer of iron?

It might have been a good idea to show the graph of nuclear binding energy and where iron sits on it to paint a better picture of what you actually mean by "nuclear ash." Nuclear forces within an atom extend between the protons and neutrons, but there's a limit to the distance this force is exerted, a much smaller limit than the electromagnetic force that pushes protons away from each other. Nick and Iron have isotopes that are almost perfectly balanced between the nuclear and electromagnetic force, such that the energy required to break down or add to the nuclide is at the highest point of all elements.

To give a sense of scale on how unacceptably dense neutron stars are, consider the following, assuming we consider a neutron star to be more or less the same density of an atomic nucleus:
•Water: 10^3 kg/m^3
•Lead: 10^4 kg/m^3
•Core of the Sun: 10^5 kg/m^3
•Neutron Star/Atomic Nucleus 10^17 kg/m^3


Essentially a neutron star is so incredibly dense that even the core of the Sun, where matter is compressed down by the entire weight of a star, is effectively NOTHING by comparison. An order-of-magnitude difference of 10^12 is hard to wrap one's head around though, so let's explore that.
We'll pretend that for each kg/m^3 the items above has, it is granted a ruler that has as many meters. So water, with 10^3 kg/m^3, would have a ruler that is a kilometer long. Lead's would then be 10 km long, and the Sun's core would enjoy a 100 km long ruler. So water is comparable to the Burj Khalifa (0.83 km), lead to Mt. Everest (8.85 km), and the Sun's Core to the thickness of Earth's atmosphere (also ~100 km).
But a neutron star? A neutron star would have a ruler around 10.5 LIGHT YEARS long! Nothing else on our list even compares.
I'll say it again: neutron stars are unacceptably dense.

The reason Iron does not fuse is because it has the highest binding energy per nucleon of any element.  If you look at the Binding Energy per Nucleon curve, Iron is at the peak and in order to fuse beyond Iron would cause a drop in binding energy per nucleon.  Iron is super stable when it comes to the various elements.

An insignificant speck of dust is all we are
Twenty-four trillion miles to the nearest star
Wandering silently in the inky blackness of space

Coughed up from the belly of an exploding ball of gas
Its cosmic entrails through which wayward photons used to pass
Our bones and blood and flesh and skin
Came from the stars only to return again

Not created by some capricious sky god's mighty hand
Rather we were forged in stars more numerous than grains of sand
Looking up into the sky the wise one contemplates
For in that frigid dark expanse his final destiny awaits

The universe is far too wondrous for any tribal desert god to have wrought
Yet through the ages this is the lie that we've been taught
To comfort us from the nagging fear of death
And give us solace after we take our final breath

Though we're here but for a moment and then forever gone
We shall in some sense continue to live on
For the stuff of which we're made shall be scattered far and wide
And seed some other world with life long after we all have died

Kurzgesagt space videos have taught me this one thing, which I think is utterly beautiful-

The universe is a vast, vast place. It is so infinitely big, that it's incomprehensible to the human mind. In this vast universe, the fraction of known living things is so incredibly tiny, that existence of life in the universe is much more closer to impossible than it is to possible.

The intelligent beings amount for only 0.01% of that tiny fraction. In this infinitely large universe, where life is infinitely improbable, you get to be a human. You get to be an intelligent being. You get to live and breathe on the most habitable planet in this vast universe that we know of.

So the next time you're having a bad day, just think about how infinitely lucky you are to be even having a bad day.

One small error:
The magnitude of the force does NOT cause the Hydrogen to fuse into Helium. There actually isn't anywhere near enough to cause it to overcome electrostatic repulsion.

This is where quantum tunnelling comes in; when you have so many hydrogen atoms, the tiny probability of hydrogen fusing into helium through tunnelling is still a significant number.

THIS is why fusion occurs NOT because there's enough energy to fuse.

our perception of an in-compressible liquid water @ 1/gcc. neutron star material 1,000,000,000/gcc. In other words a billion times what we humans consider normal. So you get things like superfluidity-superconductivity & massive gravity of millions of gee's at the surface and massive unbelievable magnetism because believe it or not protons and electrons are still present to produce effects of distortion to atoms like we cannot model. The amount of superheavies just under the surface is unreal. All this is hidden from view just under the surface. Imagine in the ocean you get 1/2 psi per foot of depth. There the gradation is one billion times higher gradation. All these effects make this object almost unimaginable. Richard Feynman's highest order of thinking (for him), was imagining using a bucket of this stuff and spinning it around to produce a magnetic field in the fluid and picturing what is happening in this superfluid. It has both superfluidity and superconductivity. Pin lines run through the fluid pinning the magnetic field lines but allowing superfluidity is an operation left to those of an autistic savant.
